history.content:
I think 186 does not require 61c but 161 does. I took 186 and 61c together and it worked well. When projects are due in the same week, you might be busy, though.

---

For 186 you'll be expected to know general ideas about the memory hierarchy (when is disk used? when is memory used? what are the tradeoffs?), bit ops, and have a decent grasp on basic concurrency concepts (what's a data race?). you won't need any specific knowledge about C or assembly. this is all pretty self-studyable if you're willing. as mentioned above both classes have non-trivial projects so make sure you manage your time if you go that route

161 gets into the nitty gritty of quirks with C for one of the projects, but if you already got through that part during the summer you should be prepared for that as well.

---

I took 61C and 186 concurrently and worked fine. For the cache replacement & concurrency part, 186 taught it without assuming you know 61C.

children.subject: 161 only requires a subset of 61C (up to around lecture 9 in the su20 schedule). If you feel comfortable with that material you should be okay for 161.

history.content: I took 61c over the summer (including num rep, C and RISC-V), but dropped it and taking it again in the fall. Both 161 and 186 seem to require 61c officially, which class is more reasonable to take in my situation?
history.subject: 161 vs 186 with limited 61C knowledge up until CALL
